name: N-(3-chlorophenyl)-3,3,3-trifluoro-2-(trifluoromethyl)propanamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4014
Reason: 3-Chlorophenyl and trifluoromethyl functional groups are known to increase the melting point due to their increased molecular weight and rigidity. The chlorine atom also adds a significant contribution due to its electronegativity and ability to form hydrogen bonds. The trifluoromethyl group can also participate in hydrogen bonding, which may slightly lower the melting point. The basic unit for this compound is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The chlorine atom can increase the melting point by approximately +100°C due to its electronegativity and ability to form hydrogen bonds. The trifluoromethyl group can also contribute +20°C due to its ability to participate in hydrogen bonding. The 3-chlorophenyl group can increase the melting point by approximately +50°C due to its rigidity and increased molecular weight.
